results.title: Eskimo winter
results.creator_credit: Richard Robinson, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey, Brian Branston, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People of the Seal”.
The second of two co-productions by the British Broadcasting Corporation and the National Film Board of Canada, People of the Seal, Part 2: Eskimo Winter is compiled from some of the most vivid footage ever filmed of the life of the Netsilik Inuit in the Pelly Bay region of the Canadian Arctic. Together, the two films provide insight and understanding of a culture now almost vanished, as they show the incredible resourcefulness of the Netsilik (People of the Seal) who have adapted to one of the world’s harshest environments. Part 2: Eskimo Winter shows how Inuit families gather in communities on the sea ice to harpoon seal as they come up through breathing holes in the ice. Also seen is the mid-winter season, a time of intense socialising in the communal igloo, with games, contests and ceremonial activities. (Awards: Salerno; Trento) Narrated by Alexander Scourby
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Robinson, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey, Brian Branston, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Stone and gum working
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “People of the Australian western desert”.
Shows a man making tools, using gum obtained from a species of spinifex grass and quartz collected from a nearby quarry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Seed cake making and general camp activity (A)
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “People of the Australian Western Desert (A)”

Scenes typical of the daily life of nomadic Aborigines of the Pintubi tribe in desert conditions, filmed in the Clutterbuck Hills area, Western Australia. The women of the family group gather grass seed. Back in camp, surrounded by their family they make seed cake.
results.title_for_label: Seed cake making and general camp activity (A)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Quandong cake
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “People of the Australian western desert”.
A woman nurses her baby daughter, then prepares an uncooked cake made by crushing and mixing in water the dried skin and flesh of the quandong fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Old camp sites at Tika Tika

results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Observation of everyday life continues, showing the women working at common tasks, mending a cracked wooden dish with spinifex gum and preparing a headache remedy from quandong seeds.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Mamu
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
A mamu is an evil spirit. Djungurai and Garimara are mapantjara, men who have the power to remove powerful bones and stones from their stomachs and use them for magic and medicine. Shows the men chasing away a papa, or dog spirit, by removing bones (mapampa) from their stomaches and hitting these along and into the ground with their spear-throwers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
